"subtitle": "Revealing The Blob."
"description":
"The Blob is a two part installation in which the viewer indirectly interacts with the network of actors that own our data and control our online interactions through techniques of surveillance capitalism, aka. The Blob. 
The user is driven to satisfy an agent of The Blob by its constant need for attention. In doing so the user comes to understand the futility of their actions and also their consequences. For every time the agent is satisfied by user interaction, it sends out data on social media for The Blob to feed on. 
The disgusting Blob grows as it’s fed and relies on its agents to facilitate its feeding - an endless cycle of attention and data consumption."
"bio":
"Yasmin L Jones creates interactive installations and post-photographic objects exploring who or what shapes the digital realm.
Current work visualises the obfuscation of the ‘real’ impacts of the internet by agents of surveillance capitalism. Often playful, these visualisations both reveal and hide these obfuscated realities, using the hidden aspects to start conversation around the intentionality surrounding what is undisclosed. Machine learning, physical computing and creative coding techniques have been used in recent works.
Yasmin holds an undergraduate degree in photography from Birmingham City University, and has recently completed the Tropical Lab international student artists programme in Singapore."

"subtitle": "A brain and heart coherence VR installation"
"description": "My final project is based on brain and heart coherence. And finding a way to escape from 3D physical reality to get into a more alpha state. My intention is to create a breathing sensor which trigger certain events in unity  the more coherent the breath. I have meditative binaural sound that I have created that I intend to loop with some parts being really distorted – almost like you are tripping out to see if this triggers different breathing patterns. The user in the VR headset will be embodied to a digital avatar lying down but able to see around what happens to their external environment when they are breathing in a more coherent manor. The audience will see the avatar from a different perspective. They will look up at the projection (almost as if they are looking up to their higher consciousness) then the projections will be from a perspective of looking down at the avatar. This will enable the audience to see what the digital avatar is doing in the headset and how their breathe affects the scene. Also meaning that not all audience members have to participate in the headset."

"subtitle": "A film written with code, English, music and architecture about human experiences of inhabiting cities."
"description":
"A Tale of 10.000 cities is a film that contains many possible portraits of cities. It is London that is filmed, it is used as a material, an alphabet with which a language is built. Code is incorporated into the structure of the stories, guided by an Object Oriented Programming methodology.			
This work is about what happens when a language is hybridised with another.
The spectator never sees the character, they discover them through their perception of the city, and a voice-over narration of one of a thousand tales. 
The purpose is to question how computation can be used to generate a grammar, with cities as an alphabet for a new language.
Programming here allows us to get close an important aspect of cities. The fact that they are hard to grasp as a homogeneous entity, and that they are asynchronous, they hold at the same moment an infinite number of possibilities and experiences. 
Code allows to convey this fundamental idea. Instead of developing a way to grasp its complexity, it instead shows a reality: cities are not graspable in a glance, and it is part of what makes them fascinating.
It is also about using technology within the production of mediums that are already widely democratised and part of our common imaginaries. It doesn’t challenge them with new imagery, but in the edition and production itself. The ambition behind this work is to use technology to trigger the same spots of sensitivity that a film previously would, without sacrificing text nor image to a seductive new technology."

"subtitle": "An installative intervention that explores intimacy and surveillance capitalism trough data sharing between personal devices."
"description":
"If located in the same physical space, smartphones constantly exchange information with each other. Our own devices datafy us and transmit those fractions of ourselves to be received and interpreted by other apparatuses. Such exchanges culminate in the creation of a whole new data profile: a fusion between external influences and the locally gathered user information.

‘equine_zygote’ explores those connections and their impact on how we experience a networked, but highly situated and monetised digital space. The central piece of the work is a cellphone which visualises the ‘handshake’ that between itself and the personal devices near to it in real-time. Furthermore, this phone has been exclusively used to interact with horse related content of various kinds. If a visitor decides to engage with the piece they are likely to become ‘contaminated’ through this data stream. The viewers are invited to take part in the experiment by sending the results of it – the inevitable emergence of personalised ads, recommended videos or pop-ups that are horse themed – to a web server. These contributions are then becoming a part of the project itself."
"bio": "Alexandra Pfammatter is a media artist who investigates the implications of transparency and opacity within systems of information. By exploring the accessibility and legibility of data or examining different perceptive and cognitive frameworks, her works reveal how such tensions create social and political asymmetries. Trough the manipulation of mediums, algorithmic processes and platforms, Pfammatter re-appropriates strategies of visibility and invisibility to revert those dynamics of control. By questioning assumption and meaning she subtly challenges the hidden structures that underlie our contemporary networked realities."
"keywords": "Data, Surveillance Capitalism, Digital Intimacy, Situated Technology"

"subtitle": "An attempt to see and tell apart reality and fiction"
"description":
"Does reality become more illegible as we come closer? Are we cursed to forever only understand a part, but never fully grasping the totality of the concept of reality? This project examines the boundaries between perception and illusion, reality and fiction. 

Closeness Quenches is an interactive installation created by combining Arduino with Max MSP. Upon entering the space, one hears distant, abstract sounds while spotting a statue inside an irregularly shaped transparent case. As soon as the viewer comes close to the statue, smoke fills the inside of the case, making it impossible to detect the exact shape of the statue. Simultaneously, voices start emerging, some attempting to describe to the viewer what the statue looks like, others lying about it or not even making statements related to the statue. The closer one is, the more nebulous their perception of the statue becomes. Perhaps in that moment, smoke and voices surrounding the statue is proof that a new reality is made through fiction."

"title": "I Thought I Saw The Face of God"
"subtitle": "A Twitter Live Stream"
"description":
"“... rather than a momentary shock, [the digital] sublime extends in time, a relentless mix of pleasure and pain without relief [...] in contrast to Kant's imagery of elevation, lift and raising over or above. The terms that describe wallowing in internet culture (deep dive, clickhole, etc) indeed suggest a spiraling down into depths—despite the obvious lack of depth to the screens we use. Is there such a thing as depth to a sequential series of flat images?” 
- Annie Dorsen

The aim of this project is to probe Dorsen’s question by creating a visual and auditory immersive environment that produces a state of both over- and under- determination.

A (near) real-time stream of images captured from Twitter is compiled and project large, so that the viewer’s peripheral vision is completely filled. The timing of the images is such that the viewer is only able to register them in retrospect, such that there is induced a feeling of constant psychological lag, which is never able to be resolved. This effect induces in the viewer a feeling of anxiety -- both of agoraphobia (as the images and meaning constantly retreat from their mental grasp), and of claustrophobia (as they are buried beneath the unending deluge of imagery and potential meaning). With all contextual cues removed the viewer is left disorientated within a sea of images which become both immanent and transcendent.
"
"bio":
"Jay Treagus is a visual artist and researcher. 
Operating in the spaces ‘between’ - particularly those opened by marginal technologies such as occultism and the trans-temporal rhetoric of afro-futurism - they explore the relationships between technology, belief and contemporary knowledge making.

Their work includes both digital and physical artefacts, installation, performance, and site specific interventions, as well as academic and fictive (hyper)texts. These forms coalesce around a post-factual position, which regards mythology, conspiracy and esotericism as immersive technologies in their own right, and the attempt to understand the ways in which they can be leveraged to do work in the world. This is a stance, which is at its heart, is concerned with developing practical tools for survival in a world which consistently defies rationalist projects of mastery.

They hold an MA in Digital Media from Goldsmiths University, and are currently awaiting the publication of their first paper.
"

"subtitle": "Playful exploration of complexity and self-organisation  through interactive agent simulations."
"description":
"Complexity is a broad phenomenon in which a system displays macroscopic properties that emerge from many simple local interactions. Examples of this include flocking birds or shoals of fish where each individual creature is guided only by the movements of its immediate neighbours and yet they produce vast dynamic shapes as a group. The simplicity of the rules and the resultant organic beauty has attracted coders and artists to emulate the behaviour - with a famous example being Craig Reynolds' "Boids". A step further from this is "Self Organised Criticality" where simple local interactions cause a system to move into a steady state, resulting in the formation of macro structures. The most famous example of this would be termite and ant colonies.  

In this piece, a system of creatures that move and leave a pheromone trail behind them is created. The direction of each creature's movement depends on the intensity of "pheromones" in their immediate vicinity, allowing for each creature to guide and be guided by the other creatures. This feedback loop emergently creates a structured pheromone map purely from the small interactions. Crucial to this and the natural systems mentioned above is the amount of creatures in the system - with too few creatures, the system will be unstable and random, but with enough creatures, the randomness falls to spontaneous structure.

By interacting with the piece your motion and presence will unavoidably disturb the natural process of the creatures and their environment until they are no longer able to survive. "

"subtitle": "When memories get lost in space and time."
"description":
"Morph means: "undergo or cause to undergo a gradual process of transformation".
Our brain, through time, morphs, and so do our memories. 

The project is an interactive installation with multiple pieces that place the spectator in the position of a close family member with dementia by inhabiting an interactive white living room where his memories are present through light. It uses technology but also combines analogue pieces. Portraits around the space get distorted with human presence or action. Going against the idea of Cornell's permanency of the photographic image in time, the pieces in this installation unfix pictures and give the possibility to deteriorate, distort, change, and disappear as happens to us human beings. These are portraits more like life itself. 

The project is also an allegory between our brain and the computer. It uses coding software in parallelism to the nervous system. Code is used to morph new images by overlapping pixels between archive family photographs. Memories are also personal self-constructions. Therefore,  live images/videos are obtained from the spectator transforming the portraits. Finally, a pixel analogue version is also part of the installation in a puzzle game. This time, instead of using a computational morphing code, the film records a person with dementia playing the puzzle. To decode and visualise the images, the spectator must place the white cubes on the projections, following up the steps of a person with memory loss and therefore experiencing and embodying his performance. 

In this installation, all constructions through deconstructions belong to a cyclical process to create a valid reality of atemporal memories. Therefore, there is no correct or incorrect portrait, all of them are possible. "

"description": ""One to Thousand Worlds'' presents non-human worlds that are different from the human world but in a symbiotic relationship. The project is inspired by Humberto Maturana and Francisco Varela's frog experiment which shows the way we experience the world depends on our biological structure . So the world we see is not the only, but one of the thousands of worlds, like mantis shrimp has an alien vision that can see 16 colors, dragonfly has a compound and nearly 360 wide vision. With the purpose of letting people immersively experience such unique and multiple worlds, I use VR technology which changes our normal human's perspective to these ones in different scales and kinds. People will have an embodied experience of these different nonhuman worlds through multiple perceptions and body movements. In this project, I want to express that although we usually focus on our own world, there are lots of other nonhuman worlds which are in a symbiotic relationship with us. We humans are not the center or the only subject in this world."

"subtitle": "Revealing The Blob."
"description":
"The Blob is a two part installation in which the viewer indirectly interacts with the network of actors that own our data and control our online interactions through techniques of surveillance capitalism, aka. The Blob. 
The user is driven to satisfy an agent of The Blob by its constant need for attention. In doing so the user comes to understand the futility of their actions and also their consequences. For every time the agent is satisfied by user interaction, it sends out data on social media for The Blob to feed on. 
The disgusting Blob grows as it’s fed and relies on its agents to facilitate its feeding - an endless cycle of attention and data consumption."

"subtitle": "A brain and heart coherence VR installation"
"description": "My final project is based on brain and heart coherence. And finding a way to escape from 3D physical reality to get into a more alpha state. My intention is to create a breathing sensor which trigger certain events in unity  the more coherent the breath. I have meditative binaural sound that I have created that I intend to loop with some parts being really distorted – almost like you are tripping out to see if this triggers different breathing patterns. The user in the VR headset will be embodied to a digital avatar lying down but able to see around what happens to their external environment when they are breathing in a more coherent manor. The audience will see the avatar from a different perspective. They will look up at the projection (almost as if they are looking up to their higher consciousness) then the projections will be from a perspective of looking down at the avatar. This will enable the audience to see what the digital avatar is doing in the headset and how their breathe affects the scene. Also meaning that not all audience members have to participate in the headset."
